Situation1: They briefly mention their day during a casual conversation at home.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, laptop open, code blinking accusingly on the screen. My husband poured us both tea, settling across from me. “How was your day?” he asked, his eyes searching for more than just a one-word answer. I knew he wanted me to share, to open up about the stress I’d been carrying. But my mind was tangled in the technical snarl of the core module I was supposed to finish today. The whole project team was waiting on me; their messages pinged in the background, each one a reminder that progress had ground to a halt because of my delay.

I wanted to tell him everything, to be the partner who communicates, who doesn’t shut down when things get hard. But I also felt the weight of my responsibility as an engineer—if I didn’t solve this, the project would slip, and everyone would know it was my fault. My husband reached for my hand, patient, but I could feel the words bottling up inside me, torn between being the open, honest wife he needed and the focused, reliable engineer my team depended on.
